prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to bin the data to ~50 km/s channels to achieve our science, however if the line is exceptionally strong we will have the option to retain finer spectra resolution. This could be especially important for detecting massive moelcular high velocity outflows.

The ALMA Cycle 0 345 GHz image is unresolved in an ~1 arcsec beam while the JVLA 10 GHz source is marginally resolved on ~1 arsec scales (Figure 1). We will maximze the SNR by using a moderate size beam while also allowing sensitivty to shape and size information. We will map the source in a later cycle once the brightness temperature can be estimated.

This is a line detection experiment with emphasis on resolving the kinematics at 50 km/s spectral resolution. The 345 GHz source detected in Cycle 0 is unreolved in 1" beam. By achieving an SNR of ~8 at the line peak per beam we will have enough sensitivity to detect the CO source shape and size on scales of ~4 kpc, and determine whether it favors the radio axis. For the overall kinematics we can integrate the flux and achieve enough sensitivy for line wings, for detecting evidence for outflows which might be jet-related.
As a continuum epxeriment we need TDM mode. The CO(9-8) line falls in BB3 at 347.8 GHz but we do not expect to detect it with this experiment.

The source is unresolved in a ~1" beam in our Cycle 0 image. The source is slightly resolved on this scale in the JVLA 10 GHz map therefore we allow for extended emission beyond 1" in this more sensitive experiment. Our beam size of 1.275 kpc will be sufficient to detemine the realtion of the strngest dust emission to the extended VLA structure.

If the flux measured in Cycle 0 of 18 mJy with 1" resolution is spread evenly over 44 0.15 arcsec beams (1.275 kpc) in this mapping experiment we can achieve an SNR of 10 / beam. Most likely the flux will be spread over a small area since 1"=8.5 kpc at this redshift, therefore the SNR will be larger overall, and we should have reasonable SNR in all beams.

Our goal is to map the emission with 50 km/s spectral resolution, allowing us to detect line wings from turbulence and flows, in realtion to the major radio structures. If the line is brighter than expected anywhere within the image we will be able to look at finer spectral resolution.

0.3 arcsec will resolve the emission into ~9 beams if it is related to the radio jets. Thus mapping with a high SNR over this area will determine definitively whether the CO emission is related to the jet strucure or lies elsewhere with the central ~8 kpc of the system.

This is a line mapping experiment with distributed emission expected over ~9 beams (the VLA sources is of order 1" in size). SNR=10/spectral channel/beam will allow us to distinguish the major areas over which the the emission occurs, and in particular whether it aligns with or avoids the radio source. It is also sufficient to distinguish emission from the core, the jets and the radio lobes if it is associated with the radio source. Tt important to establish the basic CO morphology before investing several hours of ALMA time in higher resolution mapping.
This is a continuum experiment so requires TDM mode.
0.3" resolution is sufficient to resolve the core, jet and lobe regions if the dust emission is shocked by the jets, or is centered on the core.
If the flux detected at 345 GHz in Cycle 0 is spread over ~9 beams an SNR of 10 per beam is sufficient to determine the distribution of the dust emission with respect to the radio structure.
This is a continuum mapping experiment so requires TDM mode.
The requirement for the selected angular resolution has been explained in the previous section. The LAS requirement is to have sensitivity to emission extended over a possible merger event.

If the flux measured in Cycle 0 of 6.1 mJy with 1" resolution is spread evenly over 9 0.3" beams (2.6 kpc) in this mapping experiment we can achieve an SNR of 10/beam. This is sufficient to allow us to distinguish centralized emission from extended disk or merger emission. The VLA source is slightly resolved on ~2 kpc scales so an unresolved 345 GHz source will indicate a high surface brightness of dust emission within the central ~2 kpc. This make the source a good target for later higher resolution mapping with both ALMA and VLA.
We plan to combine channels to achieve 50 km/s. If the source is stronger than expected we may be able to achieve better velocity resolution.
The 345 GHz continuum source from Cycle 0 data is unresolved in a 1" beam. We allow for a possibility of fainter extended emission beyond this.

This is a CO detection experiment which assumes the flux may be sporead over 4 0.5" (4.3 kpc) beam designed, to obtain the overall line flux and the kinematics across a line that might be 500 km/s wide, in 50 km/s channels. An SNR of 9 / beam will provide good sensitivity to line wings as well as the peak, enabling us to find evidence for turbulencs and outflows, and an overall estimate of source size.
This is a continuum experiment requiring maximum sensitivity

With 0.5" resolution we can potentially localize emission from the core, jet, and lobe region of this sources which has a project length of of about 3 arcsec. This is also enough resolution to detemine whether the flux is uncorrelated with the radio structure.

This is a detection experiment in the continuum at 345 GHz to determine whether this source has enough flux density to warrant further mapping in a later Cycle. We use 3 mJy as our predicted total flux density because a fainter source would not merit later mapping. However due to the high declination we are aware that shadowing will be significant, and we have therefore reduced the expected flux density by 35% to compensate for the probability that the source will be observed in C36-2.
This is a continuum experiment so the TDM mode is adequate.
0.3 arcsec (2.6 kpc if at z=2) is sufficient to resolve the separate VLA components and to identify which of them corresponds to the WISE source.

This is a detection experiment for a source previously unobserved with ALMA. We assume 3.0 mJy for the minimum total flux because if the flux is lower than that the object will not be worth revisiting later to map.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We address the importance of powerful young radio jets from luminous, highly accreting and highly obscured radio-AGN for the dispersal or compression of the molecular ISM and quenching or triggering of star formation in their hosts during the early stages of a gas rich galaxy-galaxy merger, at redshifts near the peak of galaxy and BH building, z=1-3. By selecting systems with a high mid-infrared (MIR) luminosity we have identified radiatively efficient (high accretion rate) AGN (confirmed by spectroscopy), and by selecting compact radio sources we have identified young radio jets that are confined within the hosts. By selecting AGN which are very red through the optical-MIR we favor highly obscured systems likely to be in a peak fueling phase, and systems which are amenable to deep UV-NIR imaging of the hosts.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.01132.S. PI Carol Lonsdale. Title: A Protocluster Traced by an Overdensity of Starbursts around a Young Radio Quasar
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.1.00397.S PI: Carol Lonsdale. Title: The most luminous heavily obscured, radio-intermediate, QSOs and the role of radio feedback in black hole and spheroid evolution.
